cab.content: LEAGUE OF NATIONS.TRANSFER 0231Till INTERNATIONAL LABOUR PEEICE, TO GENEVA.Copy of letter from the Director of the International Labour Office, to the Secre-tary-General, League of Nations.(Circulated for Information),Sunderland House," Curzon Street, London, W.l. 26th June, 1920.The Secretary-General has the honour to forward for the information of the Members of the Council of the League, a copy of a letter which he has received from the Director of the Inter-national Labour Office, . .I have the honour to inform you that the Administrative Council of the International Labour Office which has just assembled at Genoa, decided at its meeting of June 8th 1920, pending a definite decision of the League of Nations, to transfer its offices, provision-ally established in London, to Geneva.In taking this decision, the Administrative Council has not forgotten Article 392 of the Treaty of Versailles, which provides that "the International Labour Office shall be- established at the seat of the League of Nations"-. But it held that a distinction should be drawn between the -temporary establishment of the General Secretaria of the League of Nation^, in London, and the seat of the League which, under Article 7 of the Treaty, is established at Geneva.INTERNATIONAL LABOUR CONFERENCE,Palazzo San Giorgio, Consorzio Autonomo del PortoGENOA, June 11th 1920.Sir,I have the honour Sir,Sir Eric Lrumrnond K,.C.M.G., C.B.,Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Sunderland House, Curzon Street, London, W.l.(Sgd) ALBERT THOMAS. -to remain, etc2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1,, 7th July, 1920.,
